title: Law firms join forces in spirit of reconciliation
text:
Mr Mailman, Jaramer's managing principal, said there was a "great need" for legal advice "with a cultural lens" for Indigenous businesses, especially when dealing with the government.

“We can understand the real interests of these communities and how these businesses come from the heart of the communities,” he said.

The demand for these services is strongest in contract procurement, with the government-funded Supply Nation program promoting the use of Indigenous suppliers, many of whom prefer to go through Indigenous lawyers.

James Stephens, the owner and manager of Beata Terra Consortium, which helps companies meet their Indigenous procurement targets, backs this up.

"Jaramer means we can work with lawyers who understand as Aboriginal people the vision we have. It's a great benefit when it comes to dealing directly with governments and contractors," Mr Stephens said.

"It can be daunting, for example there’s [historic] issues with Indigenous people and government, so to have that there, that’s gold.”

The joint venture aims to provide all businesses with more commercial legal options, not just those run by Indigenous Australians.

Mr Cash thinks this will help the country's businesses in general.

Advertisement

“Despite there being a number of ATSI lawyers who have come through law school, there’s no cohort of Indigenous commercial lawyers. Part of this venture hopes to provide some role models," he said.

The ultimate goal is for Jaramer to thrive as a standalone commercial law firm.

“Our involvement is really about providing a jump start to get Jaramer operating as a firm that can stand on its own two feet," Mr Cash said.

"We have to crawl before we walk but it's looking promising; there's been some really good developments over the last three months."

These include gaining retainers for ongoing work and developing relationships with government bodies. Mr Mailman said the tax commissioner, for example, was "very on board".

Statement from the heart

Norton Rose is one of 18 law firms to sign onto the Uluru Statement from the Heart calling for the constitutional enshrinement of a First Nations Voice, which Mr Cash said was important alongside its “practical and tangible” work with Jaramer.

“Business has a critical role to play [in Indigenous recognition] because we’re not subject to elections and businesses are in a position to develop views of what we think is important in the communities we serve," he said.

"Businesses signing onto the statement sends a really positive message to the community generally that these are issues that are supported by business leaders.”
description: Lawyers Bevan Mailman, a Bidjara man, and Brian Bero, a Meriam man, joined forces with Norton Rose Fulbright to launch Jaramer Legal last year, in response to a dearth of Indigenous commercial lawyers.
